comments.body: nit: `onChanged` is called on user text input (it won't fire if you change `TextEditingController.value` programmatically).

Generally we start the documentation with a single sentence summary (e.g., "Controls the text being edited.") and dartdoc will make use of that: https://master-api.flutter.dev/flutter/cupertino/CupertinoTextField-class.html. See: https://dart.dev/guides/language/effective-dart/documentation#do-start-doc-comments-with-a-single-sentence-summary and https://dart.dev/guides/language/effective-dart/documentation#do-separate-the-first-sentence-of-a-doc-comment-into-its-own-paragraph
does it look better now after my changes?
nit: make the original docs in `CupertinoTextField` a macro?

This was my first though, but I noticed that `CupertinoSearchTextField` does not have a `prefix`/`suffix` property that is being mentioned in the API docs in the original `CupertinoTextField` and this may cause the docs test to fail (similar to https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/79966#issuecomment-815255754)

I see that the problem is just that the property names are different: `CupertinoTextField` has a `suffix` proeprty however in `CupertinoSearchTextField` it is called `suffixIcon`. Also `CupertinoSearchTextField` does not have a `prefix` property (it is added in the build method) so we can't reference it in the API docs.

Those are the reasons we can't reuse the docs. I will improve the docs to better describe the behavior of `enabled`.

Well this may not be as easy as passing `enabled` to `CupertinoTextField` here. When a search field is disabled the prefix/suffix widgets may need changing too (for instance, if there's a "clear" button then it may look different when `enabled` is false, or it shouldn't appear at all).
It should be clear now that setting `enabled` to false, the built-int search button and `suffixIcon` will not respond to touch events.
Should the clear button grey out if you set `enabled` to false?
Currently it defaults to grey (regardless of `enabled` being true/false). I'm not familiar with the iOS style but I would prefer to leave this as-is so people users can customize this behavior.

I think you need to update the docus of the `enabled` property to make it clear the the `prefixIcon` will not respond to touch events.

See https://github.com/flutter/flutter/pull/79966#discussion_r610371491 for context.
 Cc @LongCatIsLooong
I also updated the documentation of `CupertinoSearchTextField`.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +397,401 @@      child: IconTheme(
        data: iconThemeData,
        child: widget.prefixIcon,
      ),
      padding: widget.prefixInsets,

comments.body: Haha.  Clearly someone didn't know what the brackets were for.
